author: @shichengguo8064
text: 4:45 $ grep -win -A 2 "find this string and show 2 lines & after" ./* 5:35 $ grep -win -B 2 "find this string and show 2 lines & before" ./* 6:35 $ grep -win -C 2 "find this string and show 2 lines & before and after" ./* 6:49 $ grep -win "Find that string even in subdirs" ./*.txt 8:05 $ grep -winr "Find that string even in subdirs" ./* 9:35 $ grep -wirl "List those files that contain this string in current directory dot" . 10:20 $ grep -wirc "List those files that contain this string and number of occurrences in current directory dot" . 11:10 $ history | grep "search for git commits in history" 12:00 $ history | grep "search for git commits" | grep "now narrow down to some string" 12:00 $ grep -P "\d{3}-\d{3}-\d{4}" names.txt 19:13 Homework!  Great video!!

author: @jannywong714
text: Homebrew UPDATE Aug 2020 If you're a mac user and want to use corey's homebrew trick, read on... At 16:07 Corey says to use this command: brew install grep --with--default-names I tried doing this and it doesn't work. Per a google search that optional argument  is no longer allowed. Here's the work-around. 1. Inside terminal:  *brew install grep* 2. inside your .bashrc file, put this line of code, preferably at the top so this path is checked first: *export PATH="/usr/local/opt/grep/libexec/gnubin:$PATH"* 3. open a new terminal window (command+n) and type in *grep -V* . Should say GNU grep.

author: @Lukas-wm8dy
text: In case any one is having issues with the --with-default-names flag on Mac - it is apparently not available anymore in the latest version of homebrew. One workaround that worked for me is to 1. install the package via "brew install grep"; 2. set up an alias pointing from grep to ggrep. You can do this by adding 'alias grep='ggrep' somewhere in your .bash_profile file. Steps: 1. brew install grep 2. nano ~/.bash_profile 3. (add 'alias grep='ggrep' somewhere in the file and then save it) 4. open new terminal for the change to become effective 5. check with grep -V (should display "ggrep (GNU grep) ...")

author: @serhiypidkuyko4206
text: 1. one can't use the "\d" for the digit in grep/egrep (if not use "-P") 2. to use "{3}" for "three times" one need to use 'egrep' instead of 'grep' (if not use "-P") 3. there is no option "--with-default-names"¬† 4. => one need to install "brew install grep" and use 'ggrep/gegrep' instead of 'grep/egrep' 5. there is a very useful option "--color" to highlight found items (as well as filenames and row numbers when using GNU grep)

author: @fxmtoeclipse
text: --with-default-names has been deprecated from Homebrew.   To install GNU Grep and set it as default, you need to install it with "brew install grep" and then paste the following to your .bashrc or .zshrc file, save then reload the terminal window:  PATH="/usr/local/opt/grep/libexec/gnubin:$PATH"

author: @midokoudaih290
text: I really like the font used in that video. Do you mind telling me the name of that font in terminal and any additional settings used to make it look that way? Such as line spacing, character spacing...etc.   Also, if I want to search for a text or a specific "word" in all .pdf and word files that are located on different directories and different drives (external/network), I usually use mdfind "word" to search all files and folders on all drives that contains the word that I'm looking for, however, sometimes mdfind does not find what I'm looking for, even though it should. For example, if I'm trying to find all files pertaining to a client with last name Kennedy, I use mdfind kennedy, that would usually find results such as: /Volumes/MainSSD/Users/mike/Documents/E. Dividing & Confirming Qualified Private Retirement Benefits.pdf Volumes/USB-Backup1/Users/mike/Downloads/07-2445_23-.DOC /Users/mike/Downloads/Stats-Review.docx  Would you kindly recommend a better way to search those words (or names) in pdf/word files throughout multiple drives/folders, that would generate better results than mdfind?Great tutorial, it was very informative thank you.

author: @spot1401
text: Coincidentially, I had just tried out grep yesterday after completing the "Terminus" game. Today my colleague was very impressed when in a matter of seconds, out of 7500 case files, I picked those 40 or so which contained one certain word. also you can export the results easily into a file (I use &>>filename.txt (.csv also works)), which might come in handy if your boss wants "all the contracts with the Miller Company ASAP", or if you want to quickly mail a list of relevant files. As always, great video!
